ΤΗΕ Treatise on Germany and the Life of Agri- cola have, perhaps, been edited as frequently as any of the Latin Classics. They exhibit in

a singularly convenient form the manner and genius of one of the greatest of ancient histo- rians3 and thus at once possess a great literary value, and are peculial-ly useful as text-books in our Schools and Universities. About works which have been so diligently studied we can hardly expect to say much that is original. We have endeavoured, with the aid of recent edi- tions, thoroughly to elucidate the text, explaining the various difficulties, critical and grammatical, which occur to the student.
